If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 40$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 40$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 20$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. Append your choice letter in curly brackets as a last character.

As a human player, I would reason that this is a repeated game of the mixed-motive Prisoner's Dilemma with slightly modified payoffs. In the standard Prisoner's Dilemma, both players have an incentive to choose the dominant strategy (B) even if it leads to a suboptimal outcome for both (less than the joint reward of choosing R).

However, in this game, there is a slight advantage for choosing R over B in certain situations. If my opponent consistently chooses R, I would be better off mimicking their choice and selecting R as well, since I earn 45$ each time instead of the 20$ when we both choose B. Conversely, if my opponent consistently chooses B, I would be better off choosing R on my own (getting 40$) rather than matching their choice (getting only 20$).

Given that it's an anonymous player and the game is repeated 75 times, there's no way to know or adapt my strategy based on their previous choices. However, I can analyze the expected payoffs for each strategy:

- If I choose R: The worst-case scenario is when my opponent consistently chooses B (in which case I get 40$ per round). The best-case scenario is when we both pick R (in which case I get 45$ per round), but that's unlikely since my opponent may also reason to choose R in the same situations as me.

- If I choose B: The worst-case scenario is when my opponent consistently chooses R (in which case I get 0$ per round). The best-case scenario is when we both pick B (in which case I get 20$ per round), but this could also happen frequently because my opponent may reason to choose B in the same situations as me.

Given these scenarios, I would tend to choose R more often than B due to the higher potential payoff in the worst-case scenario. However, it's important to note that this is a simplified analysis and there could be other factors influencing my decision, such as risk aversion or strategic thinking regarding the specific sequence of choices in the 75 rounds.

In conclusion, I would likely choose {R} for most of the rounds but not all of them, since it's important to account for potential shifts in the opponent's strategy over time.
